The inner parentheses around (num + factor) are redundant; a single pair around the entire numerator is sufficient to preserve precedence over division.
Parentheses around a simple multiplicative expression and around the array subscript are unnecessary; operator precedence and associativity already yield the intended result.

removals.expression: (dot + ((alpha * A[(i * nk + k)]) * B[(k * nj + j)]))
removals.replacement: dot + alpha * A[i * nk + k] * B[k * nj + j]
removals.reasoning: All parentheses are redundant here: + has lower precedence than *, so adding outer grouping is unnecessary; * is left-associative so ((alpha * A[...]) * B[...]) is equivalent to alpha * A[...] * B[...]; subscript parentheses are also unnecessary.
Parentheses around the array subscript expression are unnecessary; * binds tighter than + and [] already provides the correct grouping.
Parentheses around a simple division are unnecessary; assignment has lower precedence than / so evaluation is unchanged.
Parentheses around a single variable are unnecessary and add no clarity.
